PRELIMINARY SUMMARY OF REPORTS OF THE SEVEN GROUPS
OF THE WHITE HOUSE CONFERENCE ON HIGHWAY SAFETY
WASHINGTON, D. C. FEBRUARY 17-19, 195**
On February 18, President Eisenhower formed the President's Action
Committee for Traffic Safety in an effort to mobilize public support at
the community level in a national crusade to curb the traffic accident
toll.
The announcement was made by Vice President Nixon before 2,500
delegates from 48 States who attended the three-day session of the White
House Conference on Highway Safety that opened in Washington on Febru¬
ary 17.
To serve as the nucleus of this Action Committee, the President
appointed the chairmen of the seven groups which constituted the confer¬
ence: agriculture, business, labor, women, public officials, media of
public information and organizations. In one broad stroke, the President
gave continuity to the work of the Conference by appointing, as several
of the groups had recommended, a permanent agency to coordinate tbs cru¬
sade on local, State and federal levels.
President Eisenhower, in his speech before the Conference, empha¬
sized that traffic accidents have been taking 38,000 American lives an¬
nually and characterized the street and highway traffic problem as “a
national problem of first importance."
